item.title: The Secret Lives of Country Gentlemen
item.description: Update: Yep. [[books/a noblemans guide to seducing a scoundrel|Second book]] delivers the very necessary half of the whole. I adored it, and now I adore this one on re-read.

item.title: The Ruin of Gabriel Ashleigh
item.description: Why yes, I’m re-reading the whole series in order, even the miscellany. Probably my least favorite of the lot, but only due to how much I like the others.

item.title: Something Fabulous
item.description: So far the theme of the year is romances that I read and then re-read right away and install on my best-of-year list (best-of-ever list too, in the case of Something Fabulous, which more than lives up to its name).

item.title: A Nobleman’s Guide to Seducing a Scoundrel
item.description: So I somehow didn’t even realize my preorder of the paperback arrived two weeks early (!!!), meaning I’ve already read this twice by the time I got the “book release day!

item.title: A Fashionable Indulgence
item.description: Ditto [[books/a seditious affair|A Seditious Affair]]: first read this years ago; out of order then in order; its politics are even more relevant now.

item.title: Something Spectacular
item.description: You couldn’t write your own story in the margins of someone else’s. I want to write something long and complex about the concept of family in this book (the Tarletons enfolding Valentine and Sir Horley and Periwinkle and practically every other stray into their own little world; the stitched-together warmth of the Delanceys’ parenting, wrapped around Peggy like a quilt; that spectacular ending of creating a new family when convention says it’s impossible).

item.title: The Gentle Art of Fortune Hunting
item.description: So sweet! Will read again, because I felt I read it too quickly. (And kind of wanted way more of the roleplay/pretext stuff….

item.title: A Seditious Affair
item.description: This was my first KJ Charles, purchased and read—I just looked it up—March 2017. I then read the whole series (out of order, of course), re-read this one in 2018, again in 2019, and somehow reviewed nary a one before 2020.

item.title: Something Extraordinary
item.description: The high-strung Belle has left behind her heroine era, and the drama-prone Rufus has left behind his Sir Horley Comewithers era.

item.title: The Duke at Hazard
item.description: I have a few auto-buy (auto-preorder) authors, but KJ Charles is the only one where I drop everything to start reading the day a new book comes out.

item.title: A Gentleman’s Position
item.description: It’s the favorite recurring KJ Charles theme: sometimes you just need a villain instead of a hero. See [[books/wanted a gentleman|Wanted, A Gentleman]] or [[books/the henchmen of zenda|Henchmen of Zenda]], et.

item.title: A Governess’s Guide to Passion and Peril
item.description: The third in the series, and I read the first two during the fugue state years when my dad’s health was failing, so I have only the haziest memory of them.

item.title: Infamous
item.description: This ending was the EXACT ENDING I’ve wanted to see for SO LONG. (Unapologetic all caps.) It took us ages to get there (more on that in a sec) but once we did?

item.title: Reputation
item.description: Lex Croucher’s lols-per-page cannot be beat. Weirdly, the only character I was meh on was the love interest, just because he’s too perfect.
